questions.text: Schematic diagram of sarcomere is given below. Red coloured structure is myosin with heads. Based on the length-tension relationship of muscle fibres, between which sarcomere length does the sarcomere allow optimal muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B to C

Explanation:

When the sarcomere is at perfect length—about 2.2 micrometres—the actin and myosin overlap perfectly, allowing the muscle to contract optimally.

The sarcomere maintains full tension as it shortens from 2.2 micrometres to 2 micrometres, i.e., from length B to C.

  • Sarcomeres are units in the muscles composed of actin and myosin filaments.
  • The amount of force or tension a muscle generates depends on the sarcomere's length.

  • Length A: Actin and myosin do not overlap; thus, muscle cannot generate tension. It occurs when the muscle is very stretched out.
  • Length B: Actin and myosin start to overlap, thus generating tension - maximum tension occurs when the overlap is just right - 2.2 micrometre
  • Length C: Sarcomere maintains full tension as it shortens from 2.2 micrometre to 2 micrometres
  • Length D: When the sarcomere length is shorter than 2 micrometres, the actin filaments overlap, thus reducing tension.
  • At about 1.65 micrometres, the sarcomere (Z disks) ends bump into the ends of the myosin filaments.
  • Further shortening crumples the myosin filaments, and tension drops to zero.
  • Thus,
    • Length A to B: Muscle cannot generate any tension (Option A ruled out)
    • Length B to C: Muscle starts generating tension, and the maximum is at 2.2 micrometres (Option B)
    • Length C to D: Muscle can maintain full tension, and it allows optimum muscle contraction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Effects of various agents on the membrane potential of intestinal smooth muscle is given below. Addition of which of the following substances produces the response labeled with B:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Adrenaline

 

Explanation:

The agent labeled as B in the effects on the membrane potential of intestinal smooth muscle is Adrenaline.

The addition of Adrenaline to intestinal smooth muscle results in hyperpolarization of the membrane potential, decreased frequency of action potentials, and relaxation of the muscle.

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) or norepinephrine acts as a neurotransmitter at noradrenergic nerve endings, inducing inhibitory potentials in smooth muscle.
  • As a result, the muscle becomes less active, and the overall contractile force is reduced.
  • In contrast, Acetylcholine (Option A ruled out) (Labeled as A) has the opposite effect. When ACh is added to intestinal smooth muscle:
    • The membrane potential becomes less negative (depolarization).
    • This increase in depolarization leads to more frequent spikes and greater muscle activity, increasing tonic tension and rhythmic contractions.

 

Cold (Option B): Typically reduces metabolic activity and may lead to decreased muscle contractions but does not have the specific hyperpolarizing effect of adrenaline.

 

Stretch (Option C): Often activates stretch-sensitive channels, leading to depolarization and increased muscle activity, opposite to the effect of adrenaline.

questions.text: Electrical activity of individual muscle cells in the guinea pig is recorded. Sinusoidal fluctuation of membrane potential with firing on the rising phase of each wave is identified from the recording. Identify the muscle type:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Smooth muscle

 

Explanation:

The recorded electrical activity shows sinusoidal fluctuations in membrane potential with firing on the rising phase, indicating Smooth Muscle.

 

Left: Pacemaker-like activity with spikes firing at each peak.

Right: Sinusoidal fluctuation of membrane potential with firing on the rising phase of each wave.


 

Smooth Muscle Characteristics:

  • Instability of Membrane Potential: Lacks a true resting value, often fluctuating between -20 to -65 mV.
  • Divergent Electrical Activity: Exhibits slow sine wave-like fluctuations and spikes. Spikes may overshoot zero and last about 50 ms.
  • Continuous Contraction (Tonus): Smooth muscle can contract irregularly and independently of nerve supply.

Cardiac Muscle (Option A): Exhibits rhythmic action potentials with a plateau phase, not sinusoidal fluctuations.

 

Skeletal Muscle (Option B): Shows rapid, all-or-nothing action potentials without any sinusoidal pattern.

questions.text: Graph below is showing simple muscle twitch in frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate tetanising frequency of this muscle.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 25Hz

 

Explanation:

The Tetanising frequency of this muscle is 25Hz.

  • Each block corresponds to 10ms.
  • Therefore contraction period = 40ms = 40/1000 seconds

 

Tetanising frequency = 1/ Contraction period

 

Tetanising frequency = 1000/40 = 25Hz

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of smooth muscle contraction is correct?

choices.text: Calcium ions primarily come from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
The latent period before contraction is similar to that of skeletal muscle
Calcium ions diffuse into the cell from the extracellular fluid during contraction
The concentration of calcium ions is higher inside the smooth muscle cell

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Calcium ions diffuse into the cell from the extracellular fluid during contraction

Explanation: When stimulated by hormones, neurotransmitters, or stretch, calcium channels in smooth muscle open, allowing calcium ions to rapidly diffuse from the extracellular fluid into the cell and initiate contraction.

  • Smooth muscle can maintain contraction with less energy expenditure than skeletal muscle (Latch-bridge mechanism).
  • Relaxation: Occurs when Ca²⁺ is pumped out of the cell or back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and myosin is dephosphorylated.

Unlike skeletal muscle, the sarcoplasmic reticulum in smooth muscle is poorly developed and is not the primary source of calcium for contraction. (Option A)

The latent period before smooth muscle contraction (200-300 milliseconds) is significantly longer than that of skeletal muscle, but it is not similar. (Option B)

The concentration of calcium ions is much higher in the extracellular fluid (>10^-3 molar) compared to inside the smooth muscle cell (<10^-7 molar). (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a primary source/mechanism of calcium release for smooth muscle contraction?

choices.text: Calcium-induced calcium release from intracellular stores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mitochondria

Explanation:

While mitochondria play a role in cellular calcium homeostasis, they are not considered a primary source of calcium for smooth muscle contraction. Their main function is energy production, and although they can sequester calcium, they are not a significant source of the rapid calcium increase needed for contraction.

The primary sources of calcium for smooth muscle contraction are:

  • Extracellular fluid: Calcium enters the cell through voltage-gated calcium channels in the cell membrane (Option A ruled out)
  • Sarcoplasmic reticulum: This intracellular organelle stores and releases calcium (Option B ruled out)
  • Calcium-induced calcium release amplifies the calcium signal by triggering further release from intracellular stores (Option D ruled out)
  • Voltage-gated calcium channels allow calcium influx from the extracellular space when the cell membrane is depolarised.
  • Most calcium ions for smooth muscle contraction come from the extracellular fluid, not internal stores.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of multi-unit smooth muscle?

choices.text: Fibers arranged in sheets or bundles
Fibers contract as a single unit

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Discrete, separate fibers

 

Explanation:

Multi-unit smooth muscle is characterised by discrete, separate fibres. This structure allows for more precise control, with fibres able to contract independently.

 

Options A, B and D are characteristics of unitary (single-unit) smooth muscle.

 

There are 2 types of smooth muscles:

 

Characteristic

Multi-Unit Smooth Muscle

Unitary (Single-Unit) Smooth Muscle

Structure

Discrete, separate fibres.

(Option C)

Fibers arranged in sheets or bundles (Option A ruled out)

Innervation

Often innervated by single nerve-ending.

Less dependent on nerve signals.

Contraction

Fibers contract independently.

Fibers contract as a single unit. (Option B ruled out)

Cell Connections

Covered by a basement membrane, insulated

Connected by gap junctions (Option D ruled out)

Control

Mainly by nerve signals.

Mainly by non-nervous stimuli.

Signal Propagation

Limited between fibres.

Action potentials can spread between fibres.

Examples

Ciliary muscle, iris muscle, and piloerector muscles.

The gastrointestinal tract, bile ducts, ureters, uterus, and many blood vessels.

Also Known As
  •  

Syncytial smooth muscle, visceral smooth muscle.

questions.text: A researcher investigating the electrical activity of smooth muscle cells comes across a specific group of cells in GIT similar to the cells in the S.A node of the heart that generates rhythmic activity without any stimulus. Which of the following will likely generate the above-mentioned activity in GIT cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Slow wave rhythm

Explanation:

The rhythmic contractile activity seen in a specific group of GIT cells is a slow wave rhythm generated by pacemaker cells.

  • Pacemaker cells of GIT are Interstitial cells of Cajal, similar to heart pacemaker cells.
  • Slow wave rhythms are due to an excitatory process, and these are not action potentials.
  • The exact cause of slow wave rhythms is not known, but two theories are suggested:
  1. Membrane potential becomes less negative when the sodium pump becomes less active and more negative when pumped rapidly.
  2. Rhythmical increase and decrease in ion channel conductance.
  • When slow waves are strong enough, they generate action potentials, which cause rhythmical contraction, also known as pacemaker waves.

Spike Potential (Option A): Generated due to the action of hormones or neurotransmitters, these potentials are seen in the gastrointestinal tract.

Action potential with plateau (Option B): Generated in single unit smooth muscle cells such as the uterus and ureter. This potential causes prolonged contraction.

Innervation of cells by ANS (Option D): This is seen in multiunit smooth muscle cells such as those of the ciliary, iris, and piloerector muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of features are characteristic of smooth muscle tissue?

choices.text: Voltage-gated calcium channels and calmodulin present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Voltage-gated calcium channels and calmodulin present

Explanation: Voltage-gated calcium channels and calmodulin are characteristics of smooth muscles, whereas Z-line, troponin and titin are features of Skeletal muscle.

Characteristic features of Mmooth muscles and Skeletal muscles:

Smooth muscles

Skeletal muscles

Spindle-shaped, single nucleated cells.

Multiple nucleated cells.

Neuromuscular junction is not present.

Proper neuromuscular junction is present.

Caveolae is present. (Option B ruled out)

T-tubule is present. (Option B ruled out)

Predominantly, calcium channels are present.

Predominantly, sodium channels are present.

Actin and myosin are not properly organised.

Actin and myosin are properly organised.

A dense body is present.

The Z- line is present. (Option A ruled out)

Calmodulin is present, and Titin is absent. (Option C ruled out)

Troponin (Option A ruled out) and Titin (Option C ruled out) are present.

questions.text: A 33-year-old competitive cyclist is preparing himself for a training program. What type of muscle fibres are important to improve his cycling performance during various stages of his race

choices.text: Both type I and type II

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both type I and type II

Explanation: Competitive cycling requires both endurance and high-intensity effort, so both type I and type II fibres are required.

Type I fibres provide prolonged strength of contraction over minutes to hours, and type II fibers provide maximal power for seconds to minutes.

Type of fibres

Slow fibres (Type I)

Fast fibres (Type II)

Size of fibres and their effect on contraction

Slow fibres are small, providing endurance and prolonged contraction strength for longer periods. (Option A ruled out)

Fast fibres are large and provide great strength of contraction for a very short period. (Option B, D ruled out)

Innervation

Innervated by small nerve fibres.

By large nerve fibres.

Sarcoplasmic reticulum

Less extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum, slower calcium ion release.

Extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum rapidly releases calcium ions

Blood Supply

An extensive blood vessel system supplies extra oxygen.

Less extensive blood supply.

Metabolic pathway

More number of mitochondria support a high level of oxidative metabolism.

Large amounts of glycolytic enzymes rapidly release energy through glycolysis.

Myoglobin

Present in large amounts, hence called red muscle.

Less amounts of myoglobin, hence called white muscle.

Smooth muscles and type II: Cycling requires activity in the lower leg muscles where smooth muscles are absent. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 23-year-old pianist comes to the clinic complaining of weakness in her fingers. She says she is unable to play a challenging piece in a song. Which of the following is the innervation ratio of the group of muscles affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1:3

Explanation: This patient cannot play the piano, which suggests that the small muscles of the hands are affected.

  • The innervation ratio refers to the number of muscle fibres controlled by a single motor neuron.
  • The innervation ratio of small-sized motor units is 1:3 to 1:6.

 

 

Difference between Small size motor unit vs Large size motor unit:

Aspects

Small-sized motor unit

Large-sized motor unit

Required for

Fine movements.

Gross movements.

Present in

Extraocular muscles (EOM) and the small muscles of our fingers.

Lower limb muscles, particularly the leg muscles, i.e., gastrocnemius and back muscles.

Innervation ratio

1:3 to 6, i.e. one single axon supplies 3-6 skeletal muscle fibres. (Option D)

1:600 to 2000, i.e., one single axon supplies 600 - 2000 skeletal muscle fibres. (Option A, B, C)

questions.text: A patient has been experiencing occasional involuntary movement of his facial muscles for the past three days. On examination of his face, minute fasciculation of his right side facial muscles was seen. Which of the following statements regarding muscle fasciculation is true?

choices.text: Can occur due to late neuronal damage or irritation.
Not visible to the naked eye and can only be detected by an EMG.
It can be irregular and brief or persistent.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It can be irregular and brief or persistent

Explanation:

Muscle fasciculation is spontaneous contractions of muscle fibres that are visible to the naked eye and can be irregular, brief, or persistent.

Features

Fasciculation

Fibrillation

Definition

Spontaneous muscle contraction of a group of muscle fibres.

Involuntary contraction of individual muscle fibres.

Visibility

Visible to the naked eye.

Not visible to the naked eye

Detected on EMG. (Option B)

Cause

Irritation or spontaneous activation of motor neurons.

Damage to muscle fibers, can occur in late neuronal damage (Option A)

Significance

It is usually benign but can indicate motor neuron disorders.

Indicative of neuromuscular disease. (Option C)

Duration and pattern

Irregular and brief or persistent.

(Option D)

Regular with a consistent pattern on EMG.

Sensory function

Usually intact.

Compromised if neuropathy is present.

EMG: Electromyography

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with generalised muscle weakness. During an electromyography (EMG) study, you observe motor unit potentials (MUPs) with consistent amplitude, duration, and regular shape. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Normal muscle function

Explanation: EMG with consistent amplitude, duration, and regular shape MUPs is characteristic of normal muscle function despite muscle weakness, which in this case is not due to any primary muscle pathology.

Motor unit potentials are the electrical activity recorded from a motor unit during muscle contraction.

  • It includes the contribution of all muscle fibres within a single motor unit.
  • Electromyography (EMG) is used to record Motor Unit Potentials (MUP).
  • The waveform on the EMG can help detect neuromuscular diseases.
    • Duration of wave - time taken for the entire motor unit to fire
    • Amplitude of wave - reflects the number and size of muscle fibres within the motor unit.
    • Shape of wave - depends on the health of the motor unit.
  • Normal wave = consistent amplitude, duration and regular shape.

In pathological conditions, such as early-stage amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option A), demyelinating polyneuropathy (Option B), or myopathy with fibre degeneration (Option D), EMG studies typically show abnormalities in the MUPs.

  • Polyphasic pattern and longer duration: Neurogenic abnormalities.
  • Polyphasic pattern and shorter duration: Myopathic abnormalities.

questions.text: Based on the tetanisation of muscle fibres, which of the following statements is true regarding the tetanisation frequency?

choices.text: It is the frequency at which the muscle fibers show visible twitching
At tetanising frequency, successive contractions fuse into a smooth, continuous contraction.
If the frequency exceeds the tetanising frequency, the strength of contraction increases.
At this frequency, there are no calcium ions in the muscle sarcoplasm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) At tetanising frequency, successive contractions fuse into a smooth, continuous contraction.

Explanation: At tetanising frequency, successive contractions fuse into a smooth, continuous contraction.

  • At low-frequency stimulation, individual contractions occur one after another, but as the frequency increases, new contractions begin before the previous one ends; thus, the second contraction partially adds to the first.
  • The total strength of contraction increases progressively.
  • At a critical tetanising frequency, the contraction fuses together, and the muscle contraction appears smooth and continuous - Tetanization.
  • Further, an increase in the frequency of stimulation does not increase contractile force. (Option C)
  • This occurs when sufficient calcium ions are maintained in the muscle sarcoplasm even between two action potentials (AP) (Option D)
  • Thus, a full contractile state is sustained without any relaxation between AP.

Visible twitching occurs at lower frequencies when each stimulus produces a separate contraction. This is known as unfused tetanus. (Option A)

questions.text: During an experimental study, a researcher stimulates a skeletal muscle with increasing frequencies of electrical impulses. The tension recordings show successive contractions that do not fully relax between stimuli. This phenomenon is best described as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Incomplete tetanus

Explanation: Incomplete tetanus is successful stimulation at increasing frequencies, resulting in sustained but oscillating tension with incomplete relaxation between contractions.

Incomplete Tetanus

Complete Tetanus

Muscles are stimulated at an increased frequency, and each contraction begins before the previous one fully relaxes.

Muscles are stimulated at a very high frequency, so each new stimulus occurs before it can relax completely.

Sustained but oscillating tension output where the muscle shows partial relaxation between contractions.

Sustained contraction where the muscle remains in a state of maximal tension without any relaxation.

The tension curve shows successive peaks with incomplete relaxation periods in between, leading to a wave-like pattern.

The tension curve shows a sustained plateau with no dips or relaxation periods, indicating continuous maximum contraction.

Treppe / Staircase phenomenon refers to an incremental increase in muscle contraction height with repeated stimulations due to residual calcium accumulation. (Option A and C)

questions.text: During a physiological study, a researcher observes incremental increases in muscle contraction height with repeated stimulations of a skeletal muscle. What is this phenomenon, also known as the Treppe phenomenon, primarily attributed to?

choices.text: Increased availability of ATP in the muscle fibres.
Faster pumping of calcium ions into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Enhanced sensitivity of the muscle fibres to acetylcholine.
Accumulation of residual calcium ions in the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Accumulation of residual calcium ions in the cytoplasm

Explanation: The Treppe phenomenon, or staircase phenomenon, occurs when the muscle contraction height gradually increases with repeated stimulations after reaching baseline.

  • This is primarily attributed to the accumulation of residual calcium ions in the cytoplasm that were released during the previous stimulation, as pumping Calcium ions back by the SERCA pump requires some time.

 

  • The height of the second contraction is more than that of the first contraction, known as the Beneficial effect.
  • After several contractions, there will be no further increase in height.

Increased availability of ATP in the muscle fibres (Option A):

  • ATP is used in the cross-bridge cycling and relaxation processes, not in accumulating calcium ions.

Faster pumping of calcium ions into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (Option B):

  • The SERCA pump pumps calcium ions back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, depleting calcium in the cytoplasm and aiding in Relaxation.

Enhanced sensitivity of the muscle fibres to acetylcholine (Option C):

  • Acetylcholine initiates muscle contraction by binding to receptors on the muscle cell membrane.
  • While receptor sensitivity can affect muscle response, it does not explain the treppe phenomenon's mechanism of increase in the height of contraction..

questions.text: During a clinical examination, a neurologist stimulates the motor nerve supplying a patient's slow muscle fibre. Graphical recording of muscle tension shows distinct phases. Which of the following correctly identifies the sequence of phases and their durations?

choices.text: Latency Period (10 ms), Contraction Period (40 ms), Relaxation Period (50 ms)
Latency Period (20 ms), Peak Contraction (60 ms), Recovery Period (30 ms)
Activation Stage (30 ms), Maximum Contraction (70 ms), Relaxation Interval (40 ms)
Initiation Phase (40 ms), Contraction Peak (50 ms), Relaxation Phase (10 ms)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Latency Period (10 ms), Contraction Period (40 ms), Relaxation Period (50 ms)

Explanation: Slow muscle fibres exhibit a characteristic contraction pattern with a relatively longer contraction and relaxation duration than fast muscle fibres.

  • A Simple Muscle Twitch occurs when a single action potential causes a brief contraction followed by relaxation.
  • After nerve stimulation, the muscle fibres go through the following phases:

  • Latent Period (LP): Period before the onset of muscle contraction – 10 milliseconds
  • Contraction Period (CP): Duration from the onset to the peak of contraction – 40 ms
  • Relaxation Period (RP): Period that follows peak contraction period – 50 ms
  • These phases collectively make up a total duration of around 100 milliseconds.

PS: Point of stimulus; PC: Point of onset of Contraction; PR: Point of end of Relaxation; PMC:Peak muscle tension

questions.text: During a physiology lab, students are studying the phases of a simple muscle twitch. They observe a brief delay between the application of a stimulus and the beginning of muscle contraction. What is this initial delay called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Latency period

Explanation: The latency period is the brief delay between the application of the stimulus and the onset of muscle contraction, during which the action potential travels along the muscle fibre and calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

  • Whenever the muscle contracts, it will produce some force known as increased tension generation by the muscle.
  • In skeletal muscle, the Simple Muscle Twitch (SMT) is a contraction followed by a relaxation.
    • Latency Period (LP): The interval between the initial stimulation and the beginning of muscle contraction.
    • Contraction Period (CP) (Option B): The time from the onset of contraction to the peak, during which force generation increases.
    • Relaxation Period (RP) (Option C): The phase during which the muscle relaxes and force/tension decreases.

Refractory period(Option A): The refractory period is the time following an action potential during which a muscle fibre cannot be re-excited, ensuring that action potentials are separated. This does not represent the initial latency period in a simple muscle twitch.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the process of tetanisation in muscle physiology?

choices.text: Individual twitch contractions at low frequency.
Overlapping muscle contractions increases total strength with higher frequency.
Decrease in contraction strength with higher frequency.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Overlapping muscle contractions that increase total strength with higher frequency

Explanation: As the frequency of stimulation increases, contractions overlap, summing to increase total force, leading to smooth, continuous contractions known as tetanisation.

Frequency Summation and Tetanization:

  • Low-frequency stimulation produces individual twitch contractions. (Option A)
  • As frequency increases, contractions overlap, enhancing total strength.
  • Contractions fuse into a smooth, continuous contraction called tetanisation at a critical frequency.
  • Further frequency increases maintain maximum contraction strength without additional force increase. (Option D)
  • Tetany occurs because calcium ions remain in the muscle sarcoplasm between action potentials, sustaining full contraction without relaxation.

Individual twitch contractions at low frequency (Option A) :

It describes the initial phase before frequency summation and tetanisation.

Relaxation between action potentials (Option C)

During tetanisation, there is no relaxation between action potentials, resulting in sustained contraction.

Maximum contraction strength with no further increase despite higher frequency (Option D):

This describes the plateau after tetanisation is achieved, not the process itself.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the order in which the motor units are recruited?

choices.text: Large motor units are excited first
Small motor units are relaxed first
Large motor units are recruited first
Small motor units are excited first

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Small motor units are excited first

Explanation: During motor unit recruitment, the small motor units are excited first, followed by the larger motor units, which is known as the size principle.

Recruitment:

  • The recruitment of motor units follows the size principle, where smaller motor units with fewer muscle fibres and lower force thresholds are activated first.
  • As the load increases, progressively larger motor units are recruited to generate the necessary force.
  • This allows for smooth and precise control of muscle contractions, starting with fine, low-force movements and progressing to stronger contractions as needed.

Derecruitment:

  • When the task is completed, the motor units are relaxed, known as the Derecruitment of a motor unit.
  • The largest motor unit is derecruited first, followed by the smallest.

Large motor units are excited first (Option A): Large motor units are recruited later in the process, as they are responsible for generating more force but lack precision.

Small motor units are relaxed first (Option B): Motor units are not relaxed during the process of recruitment. Instead, they are sequentially activated.

Large motor units are relaxed first (Option C): While large motor units might be derecruited first when the force demand decreases, the process of initial recruitment for increasing loads starts with smaller units.
